G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, “the Court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children if the Court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.”

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7(b))

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3 & 6.proposition: Jurisdiction properly lies with this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 215, §§ 3 & 6, as this Court issued the existing custody judgment and retains continuing jurisdiction over matters concerning the care and custody of the minor child.

Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas concerns removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and articulates the ‘real advantage’ framework for determining the best interests of the child when a custodial parent seeks to relocate. It does not address modification of parenting time or whether a particular midweek visitation arrangement continues to serve a child’s best interests under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Thus, citing Yannas for the specific proposition that a current midweek arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests under § 28 is not accurate authority.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "In a proceeding involving custody of a child, 'as matter of law and as matter of humanity' '[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child' (emphasis supplied)...
